title: S&P 500 edges into positive territory, U.S. stocks trade mixed as oil erases loss
text:
How are stocks trading?

The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA rose 23 points, or about 0.1%, at 34,731.

The S&P 500 SPX edged up almost 1 point, up less 0.1%, to almost 4,521.

The Nasdaq Composite COMP slumped 96 points, or 0.7%, to 14,096.

On Thursday, the Dow Jones Industrial Averagerose nearly 350 points, or 1%, while the S&P 500 gained 1.4% and the Nasdaq Composite climbed 1.9%.

For the week, the Dow is heading for a decline of 0.1% , while the S&P 500 is on track to rise 1.3% and the Nasdaq is poised to gain almost 1.5%.

What's driving markets?

Stocks were trading mixed after oil futures turned higher following news reports that a missile strike had caused an explosion and fire at a Saudi Aramco facility in Jeddah. Yemen's Iran-backed Houthi rebels have claimed credit for past strikes on Saudi facilities.

Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve's monetary policy and the Russia-Ukraine war remained in focus for investors.

“Investors are readjusting their sights for how high interest rates must go and how fast those rates must rise in order to reduce the inflation pressure,” according to James Solloway, chief market strategist and senior portfolio manager at SEI Investments Co.

The Russia-Ukraine war has been “a major shock” that risks making the problem of inflation “even more intense” before the surge in cost of living starts to come back down, said Solloway. “Even if peace breaks out tomorrow,” he said that shortages of energy, food and metals will remain a concern as Russia will continue to be “isolated” from the West.

“Investors should expect more volatility and a very mixed equity performance,” said Solloway.  “The specter of stagflation is beginning to rise.” 

Information technology XX:SP500EW.45 is the worst performing sector in the S&P 500 index on Friday afternoon, with losses of around 0.8%, according to FactSet data, at last check. The energy sector XX:SP500EW.10 was showing the biggest gains, up around 1.6%.

“Investor bias remains toward larger safer stocks with the biggest, Apple AAPL, on a 15% run-up off the recent bottom and the Dow more stable than indexes with smaller companies,” said Louis Navellier, founder and chief investment officer at Navellier & Associates, in a note.

“The focus going forward will be with companies demonstrating pricing power in the next round of earnings as inflation and resulting higher interest rates will remain the biggest concern,” he said.

Investors and economists have penciled in more aggressive interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve after Chairman Jerome Powell earlier this week said the central bank could lift rates by more than 25 basis points, or a quarter of a percentage point, in future meetings, while some policy makers have argued for half-point increases.

New York Fed President John Williams on Friday said he would support a half-point move if justified but indicated it was premature to make a call on the size of a future rate increase. Citigroup C in a note Friday saw the Fed raising interest rates in four straight half percentage point moves and then hiking into 2023, sending the benchmark rate to a range of 3.5% to 3.75%.

In U.S. economic data Friday, the final reading of the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment in March fell slightly to 59.4 and stayed at a nearly 11-year low because of high inflation and angst about the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

“Consumer sentiment has been hurt because of inflation more than anything else,” said SEI's Solloway. “People don't like it when they see prices at the gas pump jumping” or prices at the grocery store that are “materially higher” compared to just a few months ago, he said.

Pending home sales slid 4.1% in February, according to the monthly index released by the National Association of Realtors, the lowest level in nearly two years.

Elsewhere, the European Council and European Parliament reached a provisional agreement on a Digital Markets Act, aimed at tech giants such as Google parent Alphabet Inc. GOOGL, Apple, and Facebook parent Meta Platforms FB.

What companies are in focus?

JD.com Inc.JD shares fell 2.2% after the U.S. Public Company Accounting Oversight Board said it was premature to say it was close to an agreement with China on allowing audit inspections of U.S.-listed Chinese companies. Alibaba Group HoldingBABA shares dropped 2%, following a 6% fall in Hong Kong.

NIO Inc.NIO shares dropped more than 10% after the Chinese electric vehicle maker posted better-than-forecast revenue in the fourth quarter, but disappointed with its deliveries forecast.

Bed Bath & Beyond Inc. BBBY stock rose 3.6%, after the home goods retailer announced a “cooperation agreement” with activist investor Ryan Cohen and RC Ventures LLC.

How are other asset faring?

The yield on the 10-year Treasury note BX:TMUBMUSD10Y was up 13 basis points at 2.47%. Treasury yields and prices move in opposite directions.

The ICE U.S. Dollar Index DXY, a measure of the currency against a basket of six major rivals, was flat.

Bitcoin BTCUSD rose 0.9% to trade at $44,312.

Gold futures GC00 fell 0.5% to trade around $1,952 an ounce.

In European equities, the Stoxx Europe 600 XX:SXXP closed 0.1% higher Friday and booked a weekly decline of 0.2%. London's FTSE 100 UK:UKX gained 0.2% Friday for a weekly advance of 1.1%.

In Asia, the Shanghai Composite CN:SHCOMP closed 1.2% lower Friday for a weekly decline of 1.2%. The Hang Seng Index HK:HSI dropped 2.5% Friday, booking a weekly decline of less than 0.1%. Japan's Nikkei 225 JP:NIK rose 0.1% Friday, bringing its weekly gain to 4.9%.

—Barbara Kollmeyer contributed to this report.
